Anyone who finds me a fool, please say so now.

Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets.  Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ...  ... Good night.

Milt, your new book is called The End of the World.  Isn't that kind of like writing about gum disease.  Yes, it could happen, but do you think anybody wants to read a book about it?

So you're not even looking at the paperback release for maybe a year.  And it's going to be at least another year after that if the thing has movie-of-the-week or mini-series potential. You would have been better off predicting 1992 or even '94 just to be safe.

lines.speaker: u1128
lines.text: This is not just some money-making scheme!  I didn't just make up the date.  I have a strong psychic belief that the world will end on New Year's Eve.

lines.speaker: u1133

lines.text: So what are you saying?  That the world of the supernatural is your special province?

You're a poor scientist, Dr. Venkman, and you have no place in this department or in this University.

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: You volunteered, didn't you?  Aren't we paying you for this?

lines.speaker: u1148
lines.text: Yeah, but I didn't know you were going to give me electric shocks.  What are you trying to prove?

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: I'm studying the effect of negative reinforcement on ESP ability.

lines.speaker: u1148
lines.text: I'll tell you the effect!  It pisses me off!

lines.speaker: u1152
lines.text: Then my theory was correct.

lines.speaker: u1150
lines.text: You mean if I stand here and concentrate on the image of Roberto Clemente, Gozer will appear as Roberto Clemente and wipe us out?

lines.speaker: u1149
lines.text: That appears to be the case.

lines.speaker: u1153
lines.text: What's he talking about?  Choose what?

lines.speaker: u1150
lines.text: What do you mean "choose?"  We don't understand.

lines.speaker: u1155
lines.text: Tribuus!  Go left here, I want to see my new statue at Via Claudia.

lines.speaker: u1168
lines.text: Yes, Caesar.

lines.speaker: u1155
lines.text: We need more statues -- perhaps I should open medical clinics.  For the poor.  Citizens only, though...

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: It's time for you to tell the Citizens that Commodus stole the money allocated for defending the German border.  It's time to tell the citizens everything.  Will you write it?

lines.speaker: u1156
lines.text: Yes, because I know they'll read it.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: The battle was won, today, and I prefer to believe it was a gift of Janus, the eldest God of Rome.  God of my ancestors.

lines.speaker: u1157
lines.text: God of passages and changes?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I believe we are arriving in an enlightened age; an age of peace that will bring Rome her greatest glory.  Thanks to Marcus Aurelius.

lines.speaker: u1157
lines.text: You know, general, there is a Gate of Janus in Rome which is only closed in time of peace.  Sadly, it has remained open for three hundred years.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I've read of it.

lines.speaker: u1157
lines.text: But have never been?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: My only visits to Rome, Senator, have been through books.  But the war's over, time to close the door of war once and for all.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: The Senate too?

lines.speaker: u1158
lines.text: The moment you returned from the battle your options were clear.  If you are a friend to neither side, legate, you must be an enemy to both.  We needed to know what you believed.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I hope you live to see what I believe...

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: Who are you?  Narcissus The Good?  I have heard of Narcissus Meridas. That's who I hear you are.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: You're hearing about somebody else.

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: How did you get condemned to the arena without a trial?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: When the Senate and the Emperor agree miracles can happen.

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: Would you support the Senate if they would give you a trial?  You'd have to give me your word.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I need to give you my word when yours is worth nothing?

lines.speaker: u1159
lines.text: You're a citizen and a soldier.  Not a gladiator.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: You don't know how wrong you are.

lines.speaker: u1160
lines.text: Is this Rome?  Are we just going to be executed?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: They can't... if this is Rome...

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Where are they?

lines.speaker: u1161
lines.text: Hidden.  Where my brother cannot place hands on them.  He didn't have the guts to watch them die so... I took care of it all.  The sooner he is put out of our misery, the sooner will they be safe.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: If I'd ever had a sign that you wanted to rule I would have... no, again, it's my own bullheadedness. Narcissus, I should have adopted you years ago.  And now the Gods are begging me to make you my son!

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Commodus is just a young man, he'll learn what you had to learn.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: It's not because he's young, it's because he's ignorant and arrogant. His sister is a better man.  That's why I have undertaken to begin sweeping changes in the relationship between the emperor and the Senate.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: So I understand.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: Everyone talking about it?  I wouldn't wonder.  All I seek is a genuine balance of power between the Emperor and the Senate.  Thus I have transferred legal power -- which was theirs to begin with -- back to the Senators.  This includes a shared right to taxation too but some bite in the plan.  It's a start, only a start.  If the Emperor and the Senate can share power then the people will be ready to take their share.  This means Commodus has to bend; does he strike you as that type?

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: You're too hard on him.  He is a strong young man, with you as his guide...

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: A man should be upright, not be kept upright.  History shows us that a good general is quick to recognize opportunities -- even if it means making a complete about face at the last minute.  I want you to consider becoming my heir.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Marcus, you honor me, but I'm a soldier, politics scare the hell out of me.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: The Senators admire you.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: They fear me.

lines.speaker: u1162
lines.text: They fear change.  The new Caesar must be honest enough to know when the emperorship is no longer feasible.  You could be the one, the Emperor, the man who oversees the rebirth of the Republic.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: I'll do anything in my power to help you restore the Republic but I can't be that power.

lines.speaker: u1163
lines.text: Commodus must hate you.  Free your gladiators and come with us.

lines.speaker: u1164
lines.text: Are you mad?  With all this unrest the Colosseum will be open day and night!  Anyway, I'm not political, I'm in the entertainment business.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: Now look -- please --

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Ben, I think we're two civilized human beings. Do you think it's necessary to threaten each other?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: I am not threatening you.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Do you want to unclench your fists, please? Thank you. I can see in the dark, you know. I've been here quite a while.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: I am trying to tell you I have no personal feelings about you, Mr. Robinson. I am trying to tell you I do not resent you.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: You don't respect me terribly much either, do you?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: No, I don't.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Well, I don't think we have a whole lot to say to each other, Ben. I do think you should know the consequences of what you've done. I do think you should know that my wife and I are getting a divorce soon.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: But why?

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: It shouldn't make any difference what happened.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: That's quite a statement.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: Listen to me. We got -- we got into bed with each other. But it was nothing. It was nothing at all. We might -- we might just as well have been shaking hands.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Shaking hands. Well, that's not saying much for my wife, is it?

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: You miss the point.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Don't shout at me, Ben.

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: The point is -- I don't love your wife. I love your daughter, sir.

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: Well -- I'm sure you think you do, Ben, but after a few times in bed with Elaine I feel quite sure you'd get over that as quickly as you --

lines.speaker: u1169
lines.text: HUH?

lines.speaker: u1176
lines.text: I think I've talked about this enough. I don't know how far I can go, Ben. I don't know if I can prosecute or not, but I think maybe I can. In the light of what's happened I think maybe I can get you behind bars if you ever look at my daughter again. I have seen Elaine and I have spent the afternoon taking steps to insure...

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: -- before he does --  You're disappointing them, Ben. You're disappointing them.

lines.speaker: u1170
lines.text: Dad -- can you listen --

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: I'll give you ten seconds.  He is going to give us a practical demonstration of what I feel safe in saying is a pretty exciting birthday present -- and it better work or I'm out over two hundred bucks -- so let's hear it for --

lines.speaker: u1177
lines.text: What's happening?

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: Ben says he and Elaine are getting married.

lines.speaker: u1177
lines.text: I don't believe it.

lines.speaker: u1173
lines.text: That what he says. Right?

lines.speaker: u1183
lines.text: It's a short life and a gay one...

lines.speaker: u1191
lines.text: Every glass high to life -- the splendid, dangerous, mighty, brief -- brief life -- and the courage to live it.  Baron, you know -- I've only lived since last night -- but that little while seems longer than all the time before -- all the --

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Hello! Hello! --

lines.speaker: u1184
lines.text: Don't do that.

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: And the child isn't coming?

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: What? -- Who? -- Whom?

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: Good heavens. What for?

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: Man -- that's terrible. He was a nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.

lines.speaker: u1198
lines.text: I don't believe it -- he was a real gentleman. I know people... I'm so tired I can hardly see out of my eyes. No sleep for two nights and so many duties and now this killing in the hotel -- that means a lot of work. But it's too bad about the Baron, you always felt better when he came along -- always friendly -- such an agreeable fellow.

lines.speaker: u1186
lines.text: Most imposters are --

lines.speaker: u1187
lines.text: You've nothing to fear, Kringelein

lines.speaker: u1191
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u1188
lines.text: Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Call me -- do you know -- would you -- would you like to call me by my first name?

lines.speaker: u1188
lines.text: Oh, no.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Why not?

lines.speaker: u1188
lines.text: I couldn't do that, you're a stranger to me.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: You're a funny little creature, Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.

lines.speaker: u1188
lines.text: It's not funny at all. One can't get intimate just off hand. I could go to England with you and everything like that -- supposing I met you next year and I said: 'How do you do, Mr. Preysing! And you said:  'That was the young lady who was my secretary in Manchester'.

lines.speaker: u1197
lines.text: You're a deep one.

lines.speaker: u1189
lines.text: In that case give us the articles. We'll sign at once. We know all the details...

lines.speaker: u1194
lines.text: He will be on the train.

lines.speaker: u1190
lines.text: But when did he go? How do you know?

lines.speaker: u1196
lines.text: The gentleman is dissatisfied with room number five fifty-nine.

lines.speaker: u1191
lines.text: I certainly have a complaint -- and a fair one.

lines.speaker: u1193
lines.text: Four minutes past. Please come.

lines.speaker: u1194
lines.text: Come, Lisaveta, he will be there -- he will be there.

lines.speaker: u1193
lines.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car.

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: What's the matter with you?

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Bluff -- Bluff -- all bluff.

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: What's bluff?

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: That.

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: 'Deal with Manchester definitely off! "Preysing, oh -- I'd never have thought it of you.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: No one would have thought it of me. I've been getting rusty in Fredersdorf. Well, if bluff is what the world wants I guess I can put up as big a bluff as anyone. From now on...

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: You must go to Manchester at once yourself and really see it through.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Yes -- I must go to England -- I was desperate -- Now I don't care -- This sort of thing goes to a man's head.

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: What you need is some relaxation.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Yes -- that's what I want -- I'd like to tear loose -- I'd like a drink. I'd like to go down to that dancing place. I'd like to start something.

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: I can understand that -- after your -- uh --

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Say it -- say it -- my lie -- it's the first time in thirty years that I've ever... Where's that stenographer? Miss Flaemm...

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: What do you want with her?

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: I want to see her, I want to do some dictating -- report of the conference for my father-in-law.

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: She had an engagement in the Yellow Room at five o'clock -- she was in a hurry.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Zinnowitz, would you say she was pretty?

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: Pretty as a picture.

lines.speaker: u1195
lines.text: Let's go down and find her -- I need a drink -- Come along Zinnowitz.  I don't know anything about women -- been married for twenty-six years.

lines.speaker: u1201
lines.text: Bluff does it, Preysing, bluff does it. Goodnight.

lines.speaker: u1202
lines.text: Not skimming a thing, Lilly?

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.

lines.speaker: u1202
lines.text: That's right. Take a little, leave a little.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right, Bobo?

lines.speaker: u1202
lines.text: You're a thousand percent right!

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: Or else he's working an angle. If he doesn't steal a little, he's steeling big.

lines.speaker: u1202
lines.text: You know it, Lilly.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: You know, I like that suit, Bobo. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look taller.

lines.speaker: u1202
lines.text: Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: Well, you can tell them I said they're right.  I better get going. Roy'll wonder where I am.

lines.speaker: u1202
lines.text: Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: I will. So long, Bobo.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: And I'll want to leave an early wake-up call.

lines.speaker: u1203
lines.text: No problem. My husband gets up the crack of dawn.  It's his kidneys.

lines.speaker: u1204
lines.text: Here you are! Two rich people!

lines.speaker: u1206
lines.text: I must admit, Mister Fellowes, I had moments I was worried.

lines.speaker: u1204
lines.text: You brought a case? Good.

lines.speaker: u1205
lines.text: Yes, yes, but that's --

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: My son will be all right. If he isn't, I'll have you killed.

lines.speaker: u1207
lines.text: Bobo wants you to go on to Delmar.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: Delmar? I never go out to California. That's a thousand miles from here.

lines.speaker: u1207
lines.text: Nine hundred. Bobo needs somebody to handle playback this time. Come on, Lilly, you don't argue with Bobo.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: I know.

lines.speaker: u1207
lines.text: Take two, three days. Call when you get there.

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: Maybe I'll swing around Los Ang gleez on the way.

lines.speaker: u1208
lines.text: I hope you're not too badly disappointed with us, Mrs. Langtry.

lines.speaker: u1213
lines.text: It's not your fault.

lines.speaker: u1208
lines.text: You'll give us an opportunity to serve you again, I hope. If there's anything you think we might be interested in...

lines.speaker: u1213
lines.text: I have only one thing now. Are you interested?

lines.speaker: u1208
lines.text: Well, I'd have to see it, of course.

lines.speaker: u1213
lines.text: You are seeing it. You're looking right at it.

lines.speaker: u1209
lines.text: Good to have you back, Roy. I was just looking at --

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Mr. Kaggs, I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: u1209
lines.text: You're turning me down? Makes no sense, Roy.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: I guess I'm just not a leader of men.

lines.speaker: u1209
lines.text: Oh, come on, Roy.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: The truth is, Mr. Kaggs --

lines.speaker: u1209
lines.text: Perk, remember?

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Okay, fine. Perk, the truth is, I like things the way they are now. Pick my own hours, have time for, uh, other activities...

lines.speaker: u1209
lines.text: A well-rounded life. I respect that. But it has to have a center, Roy, something you care about, something you can think about.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Maybe I'm just not ready for that yet.

lines.speaker: u1209
lines.text: Well, Roy, if that's the way you feel, I won't badger you.  Don't want to lose you as a salesman, too.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Oh, I'd like to stay on. Just keep everything the way it was.

lines.speaker: u1209
lines.text: That's what we'll do, then. But I tell you what, Roy. Before I hire anybody else, I'll ask you one last time. Fair enough?

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Fair enough.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Lilly, Jesus, what are you doing?

lines.speaker: u1210
lines.text: Is there nothing I can do, Roy, nothing at --

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: NO!

lines.speaker: u1213
lines.text: Joe, could we talk it over? Do you want a drink?

lines.speaker: u1211
lines.text: My wife sent me here, Myra. For the money. She's waiting.

lines.speaker: u1213
lines.text: I'll have it tonight. Nine o'clock? Ten?

lines.speaker: u1211
lines.text: This time...

lines.speaker: u1213
lines.text: We'll work something out, Joe.

lines.speaker: u1212
lines.text: Where's the five?

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: In your other hand.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: You watch that mouth.

lines.speaker: u1213
lines.text: I'm wise to you, I should have seen it before, you rotten son of a bitch. How is it, huh? How do you like --

lines.speaker: u1214
lines.text: That's that, then.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Oh, yeah. That's that.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Well, thank you. And thank them.

lines.speaker: u1216
lines.text: Sickness comes to us all, Mister Dillon.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: That's true, Mr. Simms.

lines.speaker: u1216
lines.text: We never know when and we never know why. We never know how. The only blessed thing we know is, it'll be at the most inconvenient and unexpected time. Just when you've got tickets to the World Series. And that's the way the permanent waves.

lines.speaker: u1215
lines.text: Well, I'm back now. I just wanted you to know. Gotta rush.

lines.speaker: u1216
lines.text: Happy to see you looking so good.

lines.speaker: u1218
lines.text: Detective Carter from the Haddonfield P.D.

lines.speaker: u1217
lines.text: Toni Blake from Langley P.D.

lines.speaker: u1218
lines.text: Mind if we sit down?

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: I'd prefer you didn't.  I'm very busy.

lines.speaker: u1218
lines.text: Okay, then how 'bout we ask you a few questions?

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: Detective...

lines.speaker: u1218
lines.text: Carter.

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: ... I think it would be best if you both left.

lines.speaker: u1218
lines.text: Might want to stop and think about the safety of your students, Miss Tate.

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: I never stop thinking about it, Detective.  The only way in or out of this school is through that gate, and it is secured at all times.

lines.speaker: u1218
lines.text: Funny, we just drove right in.

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: Well, I can assure you, it won't happen again.  Thanks for your concern.  Goodbye.

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: Do you know who did this?

lines.speaker: u1219
lines.text: Well, Eddie Catero didn't show up for work this morning... parents say he never came home last night. Car's still missing.

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: Think Eddie had something to do with it?

lines.speaker: u1219
lines.text: Doesn't look good.

lines.speaker: u1227
lines.text: Another historical inaccuracy.

lines.speaker: u1220
lines.text: Would somebody shut this guy up?

lines.speaker: u1221
lines.text: Nothing to fear.  The coast is clear.

lines.speaker: u1226
lines.text: You sure?

lines.speaker: u1221
lines.text: Totally.  I checked all the rooms and closets...

lines.speaker: u1226
lines.text: Nothing's missing?

lines.speaker: u1221
lines.text: Don't think so.  But they sure did a real number on your office. Crap everywhere.

lines.speaker: u1226
lines.text: My office?

lines.speaker: u1221
lines.text: Yeah.  Oh, and they messed up your kitchen pretty good, too... Goodnight.

lines.speaker: u1222
lines.text: Better?

lines.speaker: u1225
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u1228
lines.text: Keri, you all right?

lines.speaker: u1223
lines.text: We've got to get these kids out of here...

lines.speaker: u1228
lines.text: I'll make sure there's no kids left in the dorms...

lines.speaker: u1224
lines.text: Let the party begin.

lines.speaker: u1225
lines.text: Have enough fun for the both of us.

lines.speaker: u1224
lines.text: Oh, don't be such a victim.

lines.speaker: u1229
lines.text: Aren't you gonna answer that?

lines.speaker: u1237
lines.text: Answer what?

lines.speaker: u1229
lines.text: What if it's Kara?

lines.speaker: u1230
lines.text: Mommy!!!

lines.speaker: u1235
lines.text: Danny!!!

lines.speaker: u1231
lines.text: What should I do?

lines.speaker: u1236
lines.text: Lock the doors and call your husband. Get your family as far away from Haddonfield as possible.

lines.speaker: u1231
lines.text: God ... this can't be true.

lines.speaker: u1236
lines.text: Mrs. Strode, Michael Myers is here to kill his family.  And he won't stop until you are all destroyed.  I only thank God that I found you before he did.

lines.speaker: u1232
lines.text: So they're trying to kill you and your baby. Don't tell me.  Your name also happens to be Rosemary.

lines.speaker: u1233
lines.text: No, please listen!  They're coming ... coming for me and my baby.

lines.speaker: u1232
lines.text: Come on, sweetheart -- what is this? Who's coming?

lines.speaker: u1233
lines.text: It's ... Michael ... Michael Myers!

lines.speaker: u1235
lines.text: Come on!

lines.speaker: u1238
lines.text: It's not working!

lines.speaker: u1236
lines.text: Run, Tommy!!!  Run!!!

lines.speaker: u1238
lines.text: No!!!

lines.speaker: u1248
lines.text: Thank you--for my life.

lines.speaker: u1240
lines.text: It's trash now, like mine.

lines.speaker: u1248
lines.text: New lives begin!

lines.speaker: u1240
lines.text: Somewhere in this city.  Not here, not here.  Tell Penelope I loved her--in my clownish way.  And Paul. Tell him to be a healer, by all means.

lines.speaker: u1248
lines.text: What are you going to do?

lines.speaker: u1240
lines.text: Use the sanitary facilities, if I may.

lines.speaker: u1248
lines.text: Leave the rifle here.

lines.speaker: u1240
lines.text: I'll put it in Paul's room, where it belongs.

lines.speaker: u1248
lines.text: Give me your word of honor that that's all you're going to do.

lines.speaker: u1240
lines.text: For what it's worth now, Harold Ryan, the clown, gives his sacred word.

lines.text: Hey, Willie, what was Claude's plan, anyway?

lines.speaker: u1832
lines.text: Nothing to it, really. Claude figured they could steal a couple of bodies from the morgue. They got a couple of crackers working there don't know their asses from their elbows. Then they was gonna set fire to the infirmary and make it look like those bodies was them that got stuck inside. Claude figured during the commotion, it wouldn't be too hard to slip onto one of the fire trucks and hang tight until it rolled right on out of here in the morning.

lines.speaker: u1827
lines.text: I can't believe this. I always said I'd never end up like this. I thought I'd make something of myself, do something with my life. You know, be successful. Have a big house, a family. Now I'm gonna end up just like daddy.

lines.speaker: u1822
lines.text: Don't say that, Rayford. Don't ever say that. He gave up hope. That's where you gotta be different.

lines.speaker: u1827
lines.text: They gave me life, mama.

lines.speaker: u1822
lines.text: I gave you life. And they can't take it away from you. Remember that. You'll get outta here someday. I believe that. You gotta believe it, too.

lines.speaker: u1823
lines.text: Wait for the firemen!

lines.speaker: u1827
lines.text: It'll be too late.

lines.speaker: u1823

lines.speaker: u1827
lines.text: I'm going in for him. He'd do the same for me.

lines.speaker: u1827

lines.text: Fourteen? Fifteen? Your days are running out. How long can you last? A year. Six months?  What happens when you're sixteen and you go green?

lines.text: Nothing will happen! I make the rules as I go!! Cubs do what I say! Always have! Always will! I got Cathedral and I'll never let go!

lines.text: No cubs over fifteen, Billy! Ever heard of a cub with a green flower? You'll leave Cathedral then, Billy, when you're on green, because they won't let a green stay here.  If you try to stay the young ones will gut-rip you apart!

lines.text: Shut up! Shut up your damn mouth!

lines.text: How did they get in here?

lines.speaker: u1854
lines.text: Fish and plankton, sea greens and protein from the sea.  It's all here -- ready -- fresh as harvest day. Fish and plankton, sea greens and protein from the sea... And then it stopped coming and they...  ...came instead. So I store them here. I'm ready. And you're ready. It's my Job -- protein, plankton, grass from the sea.
